title: Consolidate collection mutation endpoints into single update API
description:
Refactor collection management API to use a single unified endpoint instead of multiple specialized endpoints.

Current state:
- Multiple endpoints: add-query.post.ts, remove-query.post.ts, update-tags.post.ts, add-movie.post.ts, remove-movie.post.ts, update.post.ts
- Each endpoint reads/writes collections.json separately
- Potential race conditions with concurrent updates
- More complex client-side logic

Proposed solution:
Create server/api/admin/collections/update-collection.post.ts that handles:
- Collection metadata updates (name, description)
- Tag updates (add, remove, set)
- Saved query management (add, remove, update)
- Movie list updates (add, remove movies)
- Batch operations in single transaction

Benefits:
- Single source of truth for collection updates
- Atomic operations (all-or-nothing updates)
- Reduced file I/O operations
- Simpler client-side API calls
- Better error handling and validation
- Easier to add optimistic locking if needed

Implementation:
- Create unified endpoint with operation-based payload
- Support partial updates (only send changed fields)
- Maintain backward compatibility or migrate existing calls
- Update collections store methods to use new endpoint
- Update all admin components to use unified API
- Add comprehensive validation
- Deprecate old endpoints after migration

Payload structure example:
{
  collectionId: string,
  updates: {
    name?: string,
    description?: string,
    tags?: { action: 'set' | 'add' | 'remove', values: string[] },
    queries?: { action: 'add' | 'remove' | 'update', query: SavedQuery },
    movies?: { action: 'add' | 'remove', movieIds: string[] }
  }
}

title: Use AI-extracted metadata for OMDB enrichment fallback

1. First, check if the movie has an 'ai' field with AI-extracted title
2. If ai.title exists, try OMDB enrichment with ai.title + year from primary source (movie.year)
3. If that fails or no AI metadata exists, fall back to using the primary title (movie.title) + year from primary source (movie.year)

This will improve OMDB match rates for movies with promotional or messy source titles that have been cleaned by AI extraction, while still using the reliable year from the primary source.

Implementation notes:
- Update OMDB enrichment logic in server/utils/omdb.ts or relevant enrichment scripts
- Check for movie.ai?.title before falling back to movie.title
- Always use movie.year (NOT movie.ai?.year) for year parameter
- Log which title was used (AI vs primary) for debugging purposes

title: Exclude quality-labeled movies from SQLite database generation
description:
Movies that have quality labels (blocked, trailer, clip, etc.) should be filtered out during SQLite database generation to keep the database clean and focused on actual watchable content.

**Current Behavior:**
The generate-sqlite.ts script includes all movies from movies.json, including those marked with quality labels like 'blocked', 'trailer', 'clip', 'interview', 'teaser', 'behind-the-scenes', 'promo', 'duplicate', 'incorrect'.

**Desired Behavior:**
During SQLite database generation (scripts/generate-sqlite.ts):
1. Filter out movies that have the 'qualityLabels' field set
2. Only include movies without quality labels in the database
3. Log how many movies were excluded due to quality labels
4. Update stats to reflect the filtered count

**Implementation:**
- Modify scripts/generate-sqlite.ts around line 34-36 where movies are loaded
- Add filter: `movies.filter(m => !m.qualityLabels || m.qualityLabels.length === 0)`
- Add logging: `logger.info(`Excluded ${excludedCount} movies with quality labels`)`
- This keeps the database smaller and focused on actual content
- Quality-labeled movies remain in movies.json for admin purposes

**Benefits:**
- Smaller database size
- Cleaner movie grid (no trailers/clips/blocked content)
- Better user experience
- Quality-labeled movies still accessible in admin panel via movies.json

**Note:** This also affects generate-movie-json.ts if it needs similar filtering for individual JSON files.

Check and fix TypeScript type and lint errors
description:
Run type checking and linting to identify and fix all errors in the codebase.

## Workflow

1. Run `pnpm typecheck` - identify and fix type errors manually
2. Run `pnpm lint:fix` - auto-fix lint errors
3. Run `pnpm lint` - check for remaining errors
4. Verify: `pnpm typecheck && pnpm lint`

## Common Fixes

**@typescript-eslint/no-unused-vars**: 
- Delete unused variable, or prefix with `_` if intentionally unused
- For function params, just use underscore prefix

**Missing null check**: 
- Use optional chaining: `movie.year?.toString() ?? 'Unknown'`

**Console.log in app/**: 
- Remove or add: `// eslint-disable-next-line no-console`

**Auto-import not found**: 
- Run `pnpm nuxt prepare` to regenerate types

## Rules

- **app/**: No console.log, strict types, auto-imports available
- **scripts/**: Console.log allowed, manual imports required
- **server/**: Console.log allowed, auto-imports available

WARN Duplicated imports "FilterState", the one from "/home/linux-falko/Dev/movies-deluxe/shared/types/filters.ts" has been ignored and "/home/linux-falko/Dev/movies-deluxe/app/stores/useMovieStore.ts" is used

Option 2: Keep in store, remove from shared
- Remove FilterState from shared/types/filters.ts
- Keep definition in useMovieStore.ts
- Update imports to use store definition
- Only if type is frontend-specific

Implementation steps:
1. Audit all files importing FilterState
2. Determine if type needs to be shared (frontend + backend)
3. Choose consolidation location (shared vs store)
4. Move/remove duplicate definition
5. Update all import statements
6. Verify no build warnings
7. Ensure type consistency across codebase

Files likely affected:
- shared/types/filters.ts
- app/stores/useMovieStore.ts
- Any components/pages using FilterState
- Server-side code if FilterState is used there

This resolves the warning and prevents potential type inconsistencies.

Fix SQLITE_ERROR: no such column: rank when sorting by relevance
description:
When sorting by relevance in the movie grid, the app crashes with 'SQLITE_ERROR: no such column: rank'. 

**Root Cause:**
The code tries to use 'rank' column when sorting by relevance (useMovieStore.ts:707), but 'rank' only exists in FTS5 virtual tables, not in the regular 'movies' table. The lightweight query (database.worker.ts:203) queries 'movies m' directly without joining the FTS table.

**Solution:**
When searchQuery exists and sort is 'relevance', the lightweight query needs to:
1. Join with fts_movies table: JOIN fts_movies f ON m.imdbId = f.imdbId
2. Add WHERE clause: WHERE f.fts_movies MATCH ?
3. Use rank in ORDER BY: ORDER BY rank 
4. Pass searchQuery as a parameter

Alternatively, calculate relevance score in the movies table or handle FTS search separately before the lightweight query.

title: Fix missing information in Related Movies section on single movie view
description:
**Problem:**
In the single movie view page (app/pages/movie/[id].vue:452-473), the Related Movies section displays movie cards but is missing key information like ratings, channel names, and source badges.

**Root Cause:**
The `relatedMovies` array in the MovieEntry type (shared/types/movie.ts:147-151) only stores minimal data:
```typescript
relatedMovies?: Array<{
  imdbId: string
  title: string
  year?: number
}>
```

This is missing:
- `imdbRating` and `imdbVotes` (for star rating display)
- `sourceType` and `channelName` (for source badges)
- `language` (for language badge)
- `metadata` (for full OMDB data)

**Current Behavior:**
MovieCard component receives incomplete data, so it cannot display:
- Star ratings (MovieCard.vue:100-112)
- Source badges (MovieCard.vue:41-52)
- Language badges (MovieCard.vue:55-60)

**Expected Behavior:**
Related movies should show the same information as movies in the main grid, including ratings, channel names, and badges.

**Solution Options:**
1. Expand the `relatedMovies` type to include `LightweightMovieEntry` fields
2. Update the related movies generation logic to include this data
3. Modify `getRelatedMovies` in useMovieStore.ts:473 to fetch full lightweight data

title: Database Optimization: Split Movie Data for Efficient Loading
description: Optimize data loading performance by splitting movie data into two tiers: lightweight database for grid/search/filtering (essential fields only) and individual JSON files for detailed movie pages. This reduces initial database size from 70MB to ~20MB while maintaining full functionality. Individual movie JSON files will be loaded on-demand when navigating to movie detail pages.

title: Add admin tool to clean collections from removed movies and update IDs
description:
Create an admin dashboard button and API endpoint to maintain collection data integrity:

**Features:**
1. Remove movies from collections if they no longer exist in the movies database
2. Update movie IDs in collections if the source ID changed to a proper IMDB tt ID
   - Search for the movie by old ID in the movies database
   - If found with a different IMDB ID, update the collection reference

**Implementation:**
- Add button to admin dashboard (app/pages/admin/index.vue)
- Create API endpoint: server/api/admin/collections/cleanup.post.ts
- API should:
  - Load all collections from public/data/collections.json
  - Load all movies from public/data/movies.json
  - For each collection, check each movieId:
    - If movie doesn't exist, remove from collection
    - If movie has a different source ID that matches, update to proper tt ID
  - Save cleaned collections back to collections.json
  - Return statistics (removed count, updated count)
- Add progress tracking for large collections
- Show results in admin UI (toast or results log)

This allows more precise collection queries like 'movies from 1940-1960' or 'movies with 1000-5000 votes'.
